EXAMS CONSIDERED
IN SETTING DATES
Crist Announces That He
Holds Options On Topflight Bands
The appointment of William F.
Mehling, '39, as junior member and
next year's chairman of June Week,
the announcement of a straw vote
next week to gauge student sentiment as to bands and to the time of
the parties, and the collection of a
cash subscription featured yesterday's meeting of the June Week-Committee.
Frank Crist, '38, June Week head,
announced that he had obtained options on several topflight bands; but
committeemen complained that few
were willing to subscribe until they
knew what orchestras were going to
poll. Crist
CC featufi,
added that no band could be secured
without a down payment.
They considered how examinations
here and at Goucher would affect the
time of arrangement. Last week
Crist said that "some think its beginning should be postponed till
Wednesday, so that the Senior Ball
may wind up festivities Commencement night."
Mehling is treasurer of the Cotillion Board, junior business manager
of the Musical Club, half-back on the
football team, and member of the
Barnstormers. He is a D. U.

Geology, will lead the talk at the
Campus Discussions Group this afternoon at 4 p.m. in the Sherwood

The Ghost Still Walks

Recuperates In Florida After
Confinement To The
Hopkins Hospital
Dr. Isaiah Bowman, now vacationing in Florida following the recent
illness which confined him to the
Johns Hopkins Hospital for almost
two weeks, will return Monday to
the administration desk.
When asked in a recent interview
,
how the President was progressing,
Mrs. Bowman gave assurance of his
speedy recovery. She also added that
he will not be able to partake of exercise for 'a little while. Because of
a cold spell, Dr. Bowman has not
yet been able to do any Florida
bathing.

Young Communist League on the
Hopkins campus suffered an almost
three to one defeat in the NEWSLETTER poll of student opinion which
ended Tuesday.
With two questions on the ballot,
voters were able to object to the
Young Communist League without
objecting to extremist speakers on
the campus. However, only a small
number of voters who objected to
League meetings on the campus did
not object to extremist speakers.

EXAMS CONSIDERED
IN SETTING DATES
Crist Announces That He
Holds Options On Topflight Bands
The appointment of William F.
Mehling, '39, as junior member and
next year's chairman of June Week,
the announcement of a straw vote
next week to gauge student sentiment as to bands and to the time of
the parties, and the collection of a
cash subscription featured yesterday's meeting of the June Week-Committee.
Frank Crist, '38, June Week head,
announced that he had obtained options on several topflight bands; but
committeemen complained that few
were willing to subscribe until they
knew what orchestras were going to
poll. Crist
CC featufi,
added that no band could be secured
without a down payment.
They considered how examinations
here and at Goucher would affect the
time of arrangement. Last week
Crist said that "some think its beginning should be postponed till
Wednesday, so that the Senior Ball
may wind up festivities Commencement night."
Mehling is treasurer of the Cotillion Board, junior business manager
of the Musical Club, half-back on the
football team, and member of the
Barnstormers. He is a D. U.
